@fash_revspain As Dr Tom Stanton describes in the article, natural fibres in garment production are reliant on intensive manufacturing and advanced chemical manipulation. While they are presumed to biodegrade, the extent to which they do has been contested by a handful of studies. When fibres have been found in environmental samples, natural textile fibres are often present in comparable concentrations to their plastic alternatives, and very little is known about their environmental impact. Therefore until they do biodegrade, natural fibres will present the same physical threat as plastic fibres.

@wallawalla.berlin Synthetic fibres are man made, plastic fibres based on fossil fuel extraction and can never be regenerative, only environmentally damaging. 100% cellulose based fibres which are man made but use natural fibres such as plant material or wood pulp have the potential to be better for the environment but are very resource intensive to process I believe. Anything that is mixed/blended with synthetic fibres - recycled or not is harmful to the environment. To me, the best fibres are 100% natural like wool, cotton and flax. BUT they need to be farmed without pesticides and synthetic fertilisers and kept clear of chemicals throughout their processing journey.

@pool.berlin Over the years of our research, many brands who do not disclose their supply chains often say that it's a business secret they won't share for competitive reasons. However, not a single brand that has disclosed their supply chain has ever reported losing a supplier to a competitor as a result of being transparent – in fact quite the opposite, brands that do publish their suppliers have mostly reported how it's helped them in many ways such as collaborating with other brands sourcing in the same factories to make improvements!

@my_libelulle Great question! This is why our research purposefully targets bigger brands and retailers who have the leverage and resources to make change - we appreciate it can be much harder for smaller brands and wholesalers too, who often do comparatively more relative to their size and influence. Suppliers, agents and wholesalers often genuinely fear that revealing their supply chains and subcontractors will mean brands go directly to these businesses themselves and suppliers will lose the business, as you say. Suppliers and agents may withhold information as they do not trust brands due to imbalanced power relationships between buyers and suppliers. Therefore, there needs to be more trust and respect for the suppliers who are vulnerable in the current top-down transactional relationship they almost always have with fashion brands. It's about rebalancing that wealth and power with fair purchasing practices. Hope that helps!

Living in a country which has gone through a very rough economical patch, I have been thought from an early age to save and reuse. Of course, in my twenties that seemed like a very lame approach. Entering my thirties and seeing the impacts we have on our surroundings I’ve learned to embrace the “save and reuse” mantra. However, I do it my way - I invest in pieces I like and bring me joy, this way I know I will reuse them for years to come. I no longer buy plastic decoration and rely on natural or more eco friendly alternatives like clay, wood, dried flowers, fancy bottles. I hang cookies and use rechargeable batteries for all my fairy lights. My costumes come from thrift stores or I rely on make up. I stay away from glitter even though I love it :( My downfall is candles, as soy/bio alternatives are more expensive and don’t come in a huge variety here. 🤷🏽‍♀️
